questions.text: A 32-year-old woman is undergoing in vitro fertilization (IVF) due to infertility. The embryologist informs her that the fertilized egg has reached a stage where it resembles a solid ball of cells. What is the term for this developmental stage?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Morula

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A: The blastocyst stage occurs after the morula stage . It is characterized by the formation of a fluid-filled cavity ( blastocoel ) within the developing embryo and consists of an inner cell mass (which will give rise to the fetus ) and an outer layer of cells ( trophoblast ).
  • • Option A:

  • • morula
  • • stage
  • • formation
  • • fluid-filled
  • • cavity
  • • blastocoel
  • • developing embryo
  • • consists
  • • inner cell mass
  • • give rise
  • • fetus
  • • outer layer of cells
  • • trophoblast
  • • Option B: The zygote is the initial cell formed when sperm fertilizes an egg . It is the earliest stage of embryonic development and undergoes several cleavage divisions to form the morula .
  • • Option B:
  • • initial cell
  • • sperm
  • • fertilizes
  • • egg
  • • earliest stage
  • • embryonic development
  • • cleavage divisions
  • • morula
  • • Option D: Blastomeres are individual cells that make up the morula . During cleavage divisions, the zygote divides into blastomeres , which then compact together to form the morula .
  • • Option D:
  • • individual cells
  • • make up
  • • morula
  • • blastomeres
  • • compact
  • • form
  • • morula

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The morula is a solid ball of cells resulting from multiple cleavage divisions of the zygote . It typically consists of 12-32 cells and is the stage just before the blastocyst .

questions.text: All the following occur as a result of Conotruncal Septum anomalies except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) VSD

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B: Persistent Truncus Arteriosus (PTA) occurs when the conotruncal septum fails to develop properly, resulting in a single arterial trunk emerging from the heart , instead of separate pulmonary and aortic trunks . This is a direct result of a conotruncal septum anomaly .
  • • Option B: Persistent Truncus Arteriosus (PTA)

  • • single arterial trunk
  • • emerging
  • • heart
  • • separate pulmonary
  • • aortic trunks
  • • direct result
  • • conotruncal septum
  • • anomaly
  • • Option C: Transposition of the Great Arteries (TGA) is a condition where the positions of the pulmonary artery and the aorta are switched . This is due to abnormal development of the conotruncal septum , which fails to align properly with the ventricular septum .
  • • Option C: Transposition of the Great Arteries (TGA)
  • • pulmonary artery
  • • aorta
  • • switched
  • • abnormal development
  • • conotruncal septum
  • • align properly
  • • ventricular septum
  • • Option D: Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF) is a complex heart defect that includes four abnormalities : VSD , pulmonary stenosis , overriding aorta , and right ventricular hypertrophy . The overriding aorta, which is a key feature of TOF , occurs due to an anterior deviation of the conotruncal septum .
  • • Option D: Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF)

Educational Objective:

While it is a common congenital heart defect , it is not typically a direct result of conotruncal septum anomalies. VSDs are usually related to defects in the formation of the interventricular septum rather than the conotruncal septum .

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman is seen in the fertility clinic due to difficulty conceiving for the past two years. During her evaluation, the physician discusses various aspects of reproductive biology. She explains the origin of germ cells, which are crucial for fertility. From which of the following embryonic structures are germ cells derived?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Epiblast

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B: The hypoblast is a layer of cells in the early embryo that contributes to the formation of the extraembryonic structures like the yolk sac . However, it does not give rise to germ cells. The hypoblast is located beneath the epiblast but is not involved in the formation of the primary germ layers or the germ cells.
  • • Option B:

  • • cells
  • • early embryo
  • • contributes
  • • formation
  • • extraembryonic structures
  • • yolk sac
  • • hypoblast
  • • beneath
  • • epiblast
  • • Option C: The endoderm is one of the three primary germ layers formed during gastrulation . It gives rise to the lining of the digestive and respiratory systems and associated organs. While the endoderm is important for many aspects of organogenesis , it is not the source of germ cells.
  • • Option C:
  • • three primary germ
  • • layers
  • • during gastrulation
  • • rise
  • • lining
  • • digestive
  • • respiratory systems
  • • organs.
  • • endoderm
  • • organogenesis
  • • Option D: Neural crest cells are a group of cells that originate from the ectoderm and contribute to the development of many structures, including certain neurons , glial cells , and components of the peripheral nervous system . However, they are not involved in the formation of germ cells.
  • • Option D:
  • • group of cells
  • • originate
  • • ectoderm
  • • neurons
  • • glial cells
  • • components
  • • peripheral nervous system

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Germ cells are derived from the epiblast , which is a layer of cells in the early embryo . The epiblast gives rise to all three primary germs during gastrulation and also to the primordial germ cells . These primordial germ cells migrate to the developing gonads where they will eventually give rise to gametes .
  • ➤ Germ cells are derived from the epiblast , which is a layer of cells in the early embryo .

questions.text: Where is the epiphyseal plate of a long bone located?

options.label: B
options.text: Between the Diaphysis and the Epiphysis

questions.correct_answer: B. Between the Diaphysis and the Epiphysis
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Between the Diaphysis and the Epiphysis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Option A. In the Diaphysis: It is the shaft or central part of a long bone . The epiphyseal plate is not located within the diaphysis. Instead, the diaphysis is primarily composed of compact bone and contains the medullary cavity .
  • • Option A. In the Diaphysis:
  • • shaft
  • • central part
  • • long bone
  • • diaphysis
  • • primarily composed
  • • compact bone
  • • contains the medullary cavity
  • • Option C. In the Epiphysis: The epiphysis refers to the rounded end of a long bone . While the epiphyseal plate is adjacent to the epiphysis , it is not located within the epiphysis itself. The epiphysis is primarily made of spongy bone and contributes to joint formation .
  • • Option C. In the Epiphysis:
  • • rounded end
  • • long bone
  • • adjacent
  • • epiphysis
  • • primarily made
  • • spongy bone
  • • contributes to joint formation
  • • Option D. In the Medullary Canal: The medullary canal , or medullary cavity , is the central cavity of bone shafts where red and yellow bone marrow is stored .
  • • Option D. In the Medullary Canal:
  • • medullary canal
  • • medullary cavity
  • • central cavity
  • • bone shafts
  • • red and yellow bone marrow
  • • stored

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Between the Diaphysis and the Epiphysis: The epiphyseal plate is the area of growing tissue near the ends of the long bones. It is located between the diaphysis and the epiphysis of the bone. The plate is responsible for longitudinal growth of the bone, as new bone is added at this location during development.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with complaints of joint pain, swelling, and limited range of motion in the knee joint. Physical examination reveals warmth and tenderness around the affected joint, and imaging studies show joint space narrowing and bone erosion. Which of the following category of joint is most likely associated with this patient's condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Freely Moveable Joint

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Synarthrosis (Fibrous Joint):
  • • Option A. Synarthrosis (Fibrous Joint):
  • • They are a type of joint where the bones are tightly connected and no movement. An example of a synarthrosis is the sutures of the skull . Synarthroses are the opposite of synovial joints , as they allow no movement.
  • • They are a type of joint where the bones are tightly connected and no movement.
  • • bones
  • • tightly connected
  • • An example of a synarthrosis is the sutures of the skull .
  • • synarthrosis
  • • sutures
  • • skull
  • • Synarthroses are the opposite of synovial joints , as they allow no movement.
  • • opposite
  • • synovial joints
  • • Option B. Slightly Movable Joint:
  • • Option B. Slightly Movable Joint:
  • • These joints are also known as amphiarthosis . It allows a small amount of movement, usually because the bones are connected by cartilage . An example is the joints between the vertebrae of the spine. While slightly moveable joints do allow some movement , they do not offer the range of motion seen in synovial joints.
  • • These joints are also known as amphiarthosis .
  • • amphiarthosis
  • • It allows a small amount of movement, usually because the bones are connected by cartilage .
  • • bones
  • • connected by cartilage
  • • An example is the joints between the vertebrae of the spine.
  • • While slightly moveable joints do allow some movement , they do not offer the range of motion seen in synovial joints.
  • • do allow some movement

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Freely Moveable Joint:
  • ➤ Freely Moveable Joint:
  • ➤ It allows a wide range of movement . Examples include the knee, hip, shoulder, and elbow . They are characterized by a synovial cavity filled with synovial fluid , which facilitates movement .

  • • It refers to the ends of the long bone, and while it plays a role in joint function and stability , it is not the primary site for longitudinal growth.

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant is brought to the emergency department after a fall. Imaging studies are ordered to assess for spinal injury. Compared to an adult, at which vertebral level does the spinal cord typically end in infants?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) L2-L3 Inter-Vertebral Disc

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A . In adults, the spinal cord usually ends at the level of the L1-L2 intervertebral disc . This is the typical location for the conus medullaris in an adult patient .

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Recognize that the spinal cord in infants typically ends around the L2-L3 intervertebral disc , which is lower than in adults , where it ends at the L1-L2 intervertebral disc level. This knowledge is crucial when performing procedures like lumbar punctures in infants to avoid iatrogenic injury to the spinal cord.

questions.text: A 70-year-old male with a history of diabetes mellitus presents with numbness and a loss of vibratory sense and proprioception in both lower extremities. Physical examination reveals decreased sensation to light touch in a stocking distribution, absent Achilles tendon reflex, and a positive Romberg sign. These findings suggest a lesion affecting which of the following neural pathways?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Dorsal Columns (Posterior Columns)

questions.text: A 60-year-old male with a history of poorly controlled hypertension presents with acute onset right-sided weakness and difficulty speaking. Imaging studies reveal a hemorrhagic stroke within the left basal ganglia. Which of the following arteries is most likely involved in supplying the area of the patient's stroke in the putamen?

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient was admitted with complaints of acute pain in the right shoulder of three-days duration associated with swelling and he also had difficulty in using his right shoulder since then. He also gave a history of intramuscular injection of Iron in the right deltoid region 2 weeks previously, which was administered in a local clinic. On examination, there was a globular swelling in the lateral aspect of the right arm extending up to the scapular region. There was a local rise of temperature and tenderness over the swelling, painful restriction of the right shoulder movements and he could not abduct his arm to the right angle. questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents to the emergency department after falling onto her outstretched hand. She complains of severe pain in her elbow. Physical examination reveals swelling and tenderness over the distal humerus. An X-ray confirms a supracondylar fracture. Upon further examination, the patient is unable to flex her thumb. Which nerve is most likely involved in this patient's presentation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Anterior Interosseous Nerve

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Deep Branch of Ulnar Nerve :
  • • Option A. Deep Branch of Ulnar Nerve
  • • The deep branch of the ulnar nerve primarily innervates the intrinsic muscles of the hand ( excluding the thenar muscles and lateral two lumbricals ). It is involved in the adduction and abduction of fingers, and some aspects of thumb movements , but not primarily responsible for thumb flexion. Injuries to the ulnar nerve typically result in symptoms such as a "claw hand" deformity and sensory loss in the medial side of the hand, not specifically an inability to flex the thumb.

questions.text: A microbiology resident is lecturing on Corynebacterium diphtheriae. She asks the residents which of the following statements regarding the bacterium and its toxin is accurate?

options.label: A
options.text: Every strain of Corynebacterium diphtheriae produces the diphtheria toxin.

options.label: B
options.text: The production of diphtheria toxin is dependent upon the environmental concentration of iron.

options.label: C
options.text: The gene for diphtheria toxin production is plasmid-borne.

options.label: D
options.text: The diphtheria toxin inhibits cyclic AMP (cAMP) production.

questions.correct_answer: B. The production of diphtheria toxin is dependent upon the environmental concentration of iron.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) The production of diphtheria toxin is dependent upon the environmental concentration of iron.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A: Not all strains produce the toxin ; only those infected with a bacteriophage that carries the tox gene can produce the diphtheria toxin.
  • • Option A:
  • • Not all strains produce the toxin
  • • Option C: The diphtheria toxin gene (tox) is not plasmid-borne; it is carried by a lysogenic bacteriophage integrated into the bacterium's genome.
  • • Option C:
  • • diphtheria toxin gene
  • • not plasmid-borne;
  • • Option D: The diphtheria toxin does not inhibit cAMP production; it inhibits protein synthesis by inactivating EF-2.
  • • Option D:
  • • diphtheria toxin does not inhibit cAMP production;

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Diphtheria Toxin (DT) - DT consists of two fragments : Fragment A (active unit) and B (binding unit). Fragment B binds to host cell receptors , facilitating entry of Fragment A . Fragment A is internalized into host cells, where it ADP ribosylates elongation factor 2 (EF2). Inhibition of EF2 leads to irreversible inhibition of protein synthesis, resulting in cell death.

questions.text: True regarding H. influenzae growth:

options.label: A

  • • H. influenzae does not grow on MacConkey agar
  • • Option D. Growth in MacConkey, blood, and chocolate agar: As previously explained, H. influenzae does not grow on MacConkey agar.
  • • Option D. Growth in MacConkey, blood, and chocolate agar:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: Researchers are developing a new agent to enhance the recognition of foreign antigens by antigen-presenting cells (APCs). As part of their research, they are reviewing the physiological aspects of APCs. Which of the following statements is true regarding the functions of APCs?

  • ➤ Antigens processed

  • ➤ recognized by CD4+ T cells
  • ➤ Role of APCs : APCs, like dendritic cells, macrophages, and B cells, process exogenous (foreign) antigens and present them on their surface bound to MHC II molecules.
  • ➤ Role of APCs
  • ➤ Interaction with CD4+ T Cells: These MHC II-antigen complexes on APCs are recognized by CD4+ T cells. The interaction is crucial for the activation and differentiation of CD4+ T cells, leading to various immune responses, including helper functions for other immune cells.
  • ➤ Interaction with CD4+ T Cells:

questions.text: A gardener has multiple vesicles on the hand and multiple eruptions along the lymphatics. Which fungus is most commonly responsible for this presentation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Sporothrix schenckii

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Cladosporium is not commonly associated with lymphocutaneous lesions.
  • • Option B.
  • • Cladosporium
  • • not commonly associated with lymphocutaneous lesions.
  • • Option C. Histoplasma typically causes pulmonary infections and can cause disseminated disease , but not typically lymphocutaneous lesions.
  • • Option C.
  • • Histoplasma
  • • pulmonary infections
  • • cause disseminated disease
  • • Option D. Candida typically causes mucocutaneous infections and can disseminate , but it does not present with lymphocutaneous sporotrichoid spread.
  • • Option D.
  • • Candida
  • • mucocutaneous infections
  • • disseminate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sporothrix schenckii is the causative agent of sporotrichosis, which can present with lymphocutaneous involvement , particularly following trauma with plant material.
  • ➤ Sporothrix schenckii
  • ➤ causative agent of sporotrichosis,
  • ➤ lymphocutaneous involvement
  • ➤ trauma with plant material.
  • ➤ Ref : Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p561, 2/e p584, Jagdish Chander 3/e p163
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p561, 2/e p584, Jagdish Chander 3/e p163

questions.text: In emergency situations where there is no time for blood cross-matching, Fresh Frozen Plasma (FFP) transfusion decisions are based on the universal donor concept. However, unlike red blood cells, the universal donor for plasma is based on the AB blood group, not the O blood group. This is because plasma contains antibodies, and the AB blood group is considered the universal plasma donor since it doesn't contain anti-A or anti-B antibodies. Therefore, the safest option for transfusing FFP in a trauma patient without cross-matching would be:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) AB Rh D –

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. O Rh D +: O group plasma contains both anti-A and anti-B antibodies , which can cause reactions in recipients with A, B, or AB blood types.
  • • Option A. O Rh D +:
  • • O group plasma
  • • both anti-A and anti-B antibodies
  • • reactions in recipients with A, B, or AB blood types.
  • • Option B. O Rh D –: Although Rh negative is preferable , O group plasma is still not ideal due to the presence of anti-A and anti-B antibodies.
  • • Option B. O Rh D
  • • Rh negative is preferable
  • • O group plasma
  • • Option C. AB Rh D +: While AB plasma is suitable due to lack of anti-A and anti-B antibodies , Rh positive plasma could cause problems for Rh negative recipients.
  • • Option C. AB Rh D
  • • AB plasma is suitable due to lack of anti-A and anti-B antibodies

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Universal donor : Individuals with ‘O’ Rh D negative blood group are called as universal donors because they do not possess either A or B antigen or Rh antigen ; hence, they are generally safe. The anti-A and anti-B antibodies in the transfused O blood group are diluted in recipient’s serum, do not ordinarily cause any damage to the red cells of the A or B blood group recipients.
  • ➤ Universal donor
  • ➤ ‘O’ Rh D negative blood group are called as universal donors
  • ➤ not possess either A or B antigen or Rh antigen
  • ➤ generally safe.
  • ➤ Universal recipients : Individuals with AB Rh D positive blood group do not have both A and B antibodies or Rh D antibodies in serum ; therefore, they can receive any other blood group. Hence, they are called universal recipients.
  • ➤ Universal recipients
  • ➤ AB Rh D positive blood group do not have both A and B antibodies or Rh D antibodies in serum
  • ➤ Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Med. Microbiology 2/e p214
  • ➤ Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Med. Microbiology 2/e p214

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with acute onset of watery diarrhea and abdominal cramps. She reports eating sushi at a beach resort approximately 24 hours prior to symptom onset. No fever or bloody stools are noted. Which of the following organisms is the most likely cause of her symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Vibrio parahaemolyticus.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B . Salmonella enterica serovar Typhi causes typhoid fever , which is associated with a longer incubation period and systemic symptoms like fever and rose spots.
  • • Option B
  • • Salmonella enterica serovar Typhi
  • • typhoid fever
  • • longer incubation period
  • • Option C . Shigella sonnei typically presents with bloody diarrhea and fever , which are not mentioned in this scenario.
  • • Option C
  • • Shigella sonnei
  • • bloody diarrhea and fever
  • • Option D . Campylobacter jejuni is more commonly associated with poultry consumption and usually presents with fever and bloody stools.
  • • Option D
  • • Campylobacter jejuni
  • • poultry consumption

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Vibrio parahaemolyticus as the causative agent of gastroenteritis following the consumption of raw or undercooked seafood , presenting with watery diarrhea and abdominal cramps without fever or bloody stools .
  • ➤ Vibrio parahaemolyticus
  • ➤ gastroenteritis
  • ➤ consumption of raw
  • ➤ undercooked seafood
  • ➤ watery diarrhea and abdominal cramps without fever or bloody stools
  • ➤ Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Med Microbiology 1/e p337, 2/e p350
  • ➤ Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Med Microbiology 1/e p337, 2/e p350

questions.text: A research team is studying the role of macrophages in the immune response. They are particularly interested in the cytokines produced by macrophages and their effects. Which cytokine is predominantly produced by macrophages?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A)  IL-1

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. IL-5 : Mainly produced by T cells , involved in eosinophil activation.
  • • Option B. IL-5
  • • Mainly produced by T cells
  • • eosinophil activation.
  • • Option C. IL-7 : Important for lymphocyte development , not predominantly produced by macrophages.
  • • Option C. IL-7
  • • lymphocyte development
  • • Option D. IFN-γ : Mainly produced by T cells and NK cells , not primarily by macrophages.
  • • Option D. IFN-γ
  • • produced by T cells and NK cells

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objectives:
  • ➤ Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p153-4, 2/e p159-160, Kuby’s Immunology 6/e p209 Macrophage produces various secretory molecules

questions.text: A 55-year-old man with a history of chronic liver disease presents to the clinic with a two-day history of fever and severe pain in his right leg. He reports a recent trip to a coastal region where he consumed raw oysters. On examination, his right leg is erythematous with a rapidly progressing edema and hemorrhagic bullae. Which of the following organisms, known for requiring high salt concentrations for growth, is the most likely cause of his symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Vibrio vulnificus.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A . Vibrio cholerae is incorrect because while it is associated with seafood , it typically causes profuse watery diarrhea known as rice-water stools and is not known for causing wound infections or bullae.
  • • Option A
  • • Vibrio cholerae
  • • associated with seafood
  • • causes profuse watery diarrhea
  • • Option B . Vibrio parahaemolyticus is incorrect because it usually causes gastroenteritis with watery diarrhea following the consumption of undercooked or raw seafood. It is less commonly associated with wound infections compared to Vibrio vulnificus.
  • • Option B
  • • Vibrio parahaemolyticus
  • • causes gastroenteritis with watery diarrhea
  • • Option D. Vibrio alginolyticus is incorrect because it is more commonly associated with ear infections and less virulent than Vibrio vulnificus.
  • • Option D.
  • • Vibrio alginolyticus
  • • associated with ear infections

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Vibrio vulnificus is a halophilic bacterium found in marine environments , known for causing severe illnesses , especially in individuals with liver conditions . Infections can lead to wound infections , septicemia , and distinctive cellulitis with bullous lesions .
  • ➤ Vibrio vulnificus
  • ➤ halophilic bacterium
  • ➤ marine environments
  • ➤ severe illnesses
  • ➤ liver conditions
  • ➤ lead to wound infections
  • ➤ septicemia
  • ➤ distinctive cellulitis with bullous lesions
  • ➤ Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Med. Microbiology 2/e 341
  • ➤ Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Med. Microbiology 2/e 341

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents to the clinic with complaints of intermittent diarrhea, abdominal pain, and weight loss for the past six months. He immigrated from a tropical country two years ago and has no significant past medical history. His physical examination is unremarkable. Laboratory investigations reveal eosinophilia. Stool examination shows larva currens. Which of the following organisms is most likely responsible for his symptoms through a mechanism of autoinfection?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Strongyloides

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A . Cryptosporidium : Causes cryptosporidiosis, typically presenting with watery diarrhea . It does not cause autoinfection.
  • • Option A
  • • Cryptosporidium
  • • watery diarrhea
  • • Option C . Giardia : Giardiasis can cause diarrhea and abdominal pain but does not involve autoinfection and is less likely to cause eosinophilia.
  • • Option C
  • • Giardia
  • • cause diarrhea and abdominal pain
  • • Option D . Gnathostoma : It is a nematode causing gnathostomiasis , associated with migratory skin lesions and eosinophilia but does not undergo autoinfection.
  • • Option D
  • • Gnathostoma
  • • nematode causing gnathostomiasis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In patients with a history of residence in or travel to tropical regions presenting with gastrointestinal symptoms and eosinophilia, Strongyloides stercoralis should be considered. Strongyloidiasis is unique among intestinal helminths due to its ability to cause autoinfection , leading to persistent infections that can last for decades, particularly in immunocompromised individuals.
  • ➤ travel to tropical regions
  • ➤ gastrointestinal symptoms
  • ➤ eosinophilia, Strongyloides stercoralis
  • ➤ Strongyloidiasis is unique among intestinal helminths
  • ➤ ability to cause autoinfection
  • ➤ persistent infections
  • ➤ last for decades,
  • ➤ Ref : Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Parasitology 1/e p5, 2/e p5
  • ➤ Ref :
  • ➤ Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Parasitology 1/e p5, 2/e p5
